sentence:
We denote by K  L = (Kâˆ– L) âˆª (Lâˆ– K) the symmetric difference between two sets K, L, and by d(K,L) = |K L| the symmetric difference distance between these sets. (All the sets considered in this chapter are finite.) The symbols â€œ+ and âŠ‚ stand for the disjoint union  and the proper inclusion of sets  respectively. A (knowledge) structure is a pair
(Q,) where Q is a non empty set and  is a family of subsets of Q containing   and Q=âˆª. The latter is called the  domain of (Q,). The elements of Q are called items and the sets in  are  (knowledge) states. Since Q =âˆª,  the set Q is implicitly defined  by  and we can without ambiguity call  a knowledge structure. A knowledge structure   is wellâ€“graded if for any two distinct states K and L with |Kâ–³ L| = n there exists a sequence
K_0=K,K_1,â€¦, K_n= L 
such that d(K,L) = n and d(K_i, K_i+1)=1 for 0â‰¤ iâ‰¤ n-1. 
We call such a sequence K_0=K,K_1,â€¦, K_n= L a tight path from K toÂ L. 
We say that  is a knowledge space if it is closed under union, or âˆª-closed . 

A knowledge structure (Q,) is a learning space <cit.> if it satisfies the following two conditions: 


 
  [L1] Learning smoothness. For any two K,Lâˆˆ, with K âŠ‚ L and |Lâˆ– K| = n, there is a chain 
K_0=K âŠ‚  K_1âŠ‚â‹¯âŠ‚ K_n = L  
such that, for 0â‰¤ iâ‰¤ n-1, we have K_i+1 = K_i + {q_i}âˆˆ for some q_iâˆˆ Q . 



  [L2] Learning consistency. If K âŠ‚ L are two sets in  such that K + {q}âˆˆ for some qâˆˆ Q, then  L âˆª{q}âˆˆ.  
A learning space is also known in the combinatorics literature as an `antimatroid', a structure introduced independently by <cit.> with slightly different, but equivalent axioms <cit.>. Another name is `wellâ€“graded knowledge space' <cit.>; see our LemmaÂ <ref>. 

A family   of subsets of a set Q is a partial knowledge structure if it contains the set Q=âˆª. We do not assume that ||â‰¥ 2.  
We also call `states' the sets in .  A partial knowledge structure   is a partial learning space  if it satisfies Axioms [L1] and [L2]. Note that  {} is vacuously well-graded and vacuously  âˆª-closed, with âˆª{}=. Thus, it  a partial knowledge structure  and a partial learning space (cf.Â Lemma <ref>).

sentence:
Given an arbitrary finite word v_1â‹¯ v_n, its q-shuffle
is the
random word w_1â‹¯ w_n obtained by a random permutation of the letters
v_1,â€¦,v_n, determined by the following n-step algorithm (not
to be
confused with the notion of a-shuffle with integer parameter a; see
<cit.>).

Let Î¾_1,â€¦,Î¾_n be independent random variables with Î¾
_j having
distribution G_q,n-j+1.

At step 1, take for w_1 the Î¾_1th letter from the word
v^(1):=v_1â‹¯
v_n. Then, remove the letter v_Î¾_1 from v^(1) and denote by
v^(2)
the resulting word of length n-1. Iterate. So, at each following step
m=2,â€¦,n, there is a word v^(m) which was derived from the
initial word
by deleting some m-1 letters, a new letter w_m=v^(m)_Î¾_m is then
chosen and, if m<n, the word v^(m+1) is obtained by removing this letter
from v^(m).

sentence:
We will refer to 3 different types of normal vectors for the
boundaries between victory regions.

 
  * A Type 1 vector only satisfies the requirements necessary for the boundary between 2 particular victory regions.
 
  * A Type 2 vector satisfies the requirements for all of the boundaries to the victory region for a single candidate c_i.
 
  * A Type 3 vector satisfies the requirements for all of the boundaries between all of the victory regions defined by this election method.

sentence:
A Young diagram is a collection of boxes arranged in left-justified rows, with a weakly decreasing number of boxes in each row. A Young tableau is a filling of a Young diagram that is

Every Young diagram corresponds to a partition Î», and we define the shape of a Young tableau to be the partition that corresponds to the Young diagram.

Flipping a Young diagram Î» over its main diagonal (from upper left to lower right) gives the conjugate diagram, denoted Î»'.

sentence:
[Integer Programming Game]
An integer programming game with n players is a noncooperative game where the S_i of actions for each player i is the set of lattice points inside a polytope; that is,

    S_i=P_iâˆ©^d_i

where P_i = { x âˆˆ^d_i:M_i x â‰¤ b_i} is a rational polytope.

Let I = {1,â€¦,n} denote the set of players. The set S of action profiles s = ( s_1,â€¦, s_n) is the Cartesian product of the S_i's:

    S=âˆ_i=1^n S_i âŠ†^d

where d = d_1+â‹¯+d_n. The payoff functions are integer-valued of the form u_i:Sâ†’ for i âˆˆ I.

An integer-valued payoff function u:Sâ†’ of a game is a difference of piecewise-linear convex functions or DPLC function if it can be expressed as:

where the f_k and g_l are affine functions with integer coefficients and where K and L are finite index sets. We refer to the f_k as the â€œconvex" pieces of u and the g_l as the â€œconcave" pieces of u.

  is a coedge.

  nonzero Â± e_i^* are among the shortest

sentence:

sentence:
An entry T(i,j) in a Young composition tableau T is said to be virtuous if the following hold.


  * The entry T(i,j)  is greater than all entries below it in its column.

  * The entry T(i,j) is at the end of its row.

  * Any other element which is at the end of its row in column i is in a row above j.

sentence:
A planar X-labelled rooted tree is a planar rooted treeÂ T with no internal vertices having exactly one child, and with a labelling of all vertices fulfilling the following restrictions: 

 
  - every internal vertexÂ v with m children is labelled by an element x_vâˆˆ X_m;
 
  - every leaf ofÂ T is labelled by a positive integer in such a way that the following two conditions are satisfied:
 
  
  * (labelling set condition) the leaf labels are in one-to-one correspondence with the set [l]={1,2,â€¦,l} (where l is the number of leaves of T);
  
  * (local increasing condition) if we temporarily assign to each internal vertex v the smallest of the labels of leaves that are descendants ofÂ v inÂ T  (thus every vertex of T, should it be an internal vertex or a leaf, has an integer assigned to it), then for each internal vertex i the integers assigned to its children increase from the left to the right.
 

Notation: for iâ‰¥ 0, lâ‰¥ 1 we denote by â„’ğ’¯_i,l(X) the set of planar X-labelled rooted trees withÂ i internal vertices and l leaves, 

    â„’ğ’¯_l(X)=â‹ƒ_iâ‰¥ 0â„’ğ’¯_i,l(X)

is the set of planar X-labelled rooted trees with l leaves, 

    â„’ğ’¯(X)=â‹ƒ_iâ‰¥ 0, lâ‰¥ 1â„’ğ’¯_i,l(X)

is the set of all planar X-labelled rooted trees. In particular, â„’ğ’¯_0,l(X) is non-empty only for l=1 (and in that case it consists of exactly one element, a one-vertex tree with no edges), and â„’ğ’¯_1(X)=â„’ğ’¯_0,1(X) (since every internal vertex has at least two children, hence in the presence of an internal vertex we end up with at least two leaves).

sentence:
Node n_i is forward-connected to node-n_j if and only if there exists an additive combination of k_1th, k_2th, â‹¯, k_pth and jth columns of ğ€ such that  C^ğ€_k_1+C^ğ€_k_2+â‹¯+C^ğ€_k_p+C^ğ€_j=X_j^N-X_i^N where i<k_1<k_2<...<k_p<j.
	
		Necessity: n_i is forward connected to n_j. This means either n_i is forward-adjacent to n_j, i.e., C^ğ€_j=X_j^N-X_i^N, in which case the condition is proved; or there exists a sequence of forward-connected nodes in between n_i and n_j that creates the route R_iâ†’ j. For the latter case, nodes n_k_1,Â n_k_2,Â ...,Â n_k_p exist with i<k_1<k_2<...<k_p<j such that
		
			
  * n_i is forward adjacent to n_k_1 â‡’ C^ğ€_k_1=X_k_1^N-X_i^N
			
  * each n_k_Î² is forward-adjacent to n_k_Î²+1Â âˆ€Â  1<Î²<p-1 Â Â â‡’ C^ğ€_k_Î²+1=X_k_Î²+1^N-X_k_Î²^N
			
  * n_k_p is forward adjacent to n_j â‡’ C^ğ€_j=X_j^N-X_k_p^N
		
	(Note: k_1, k_2, ..., k_p are not necessarily consecutive integers.) Now, clearly the sum C^ğ€_k_1+C^ğ€_k_2+â‹¯+C^ğ€_k_p+C^ğ€_j is equal to X_j^N-X_i^N. Thus, the condition is necessary.
	
	Sufficiency: There exists an additive combination C^ğ€_k_1+C^ğ€_k_2+â‹¯+C^ğ€_k_p+C^ğ€_j with i<k_1<k_2<...<k_p<j such that the sum is X_j^N-X_i^N. It is required to prove that n_i is forward connected to n_j. Let, C^ğ€_k_1=X_k_1^N-X_k_1'^N, C^ğ€_k_2=X_k_2^N-X_k_2'^N, ..., C^ğ€_k_p=X_k_p^N-X_k_p'^N, C^ğ€_j=X_j^N-X_j'^N (this consideration is based on LemmaÂ <ref>). Now,
	
    X_j^N-X_i^N    =    C^ğ€_k_1+C^ğ€_k_2+â‹¯+C^ğ€_k_p+C^ğ€_j
       =    (X_k_1^N-X_k_1'^N)+(X_k_2^N-X_k_2'^N)+...+(X_k_p^N-X_k_p'^N)+(X_j^N-X_j'^N)
       =    (X_k_1^N+X_k_2^N+...+X_k_p^N)+X_j^N-(X_k_1'^N+X_k_2'^N+...+X_k_p'^N+X_j'^N)
    â‡’ X_k_1'^N+X_k_2'^N+...+X_k_p'^N+X_j'^N    =    (X_k_1^N+X_k_2^N+...+X_k_p^N)+X_i^N

	In (<ref>), it is easily seen that both sides contain p+1 vectors and vectors in the right hand side are mutually independent. Thus, by Fact-III, each column in the left hand side should be equal to one in the right side.
	
	Now consider X_k_1'. C_k_1^ğ€=X_k_1-X_k_1' and therefore k_1'â‰  k_1. If X_k_1'= X_k_Î² where Î²>1, this would imply k_1'=k_Î²>k_1 which is a contradiction since k_1<k_2<...<k_p. Therefore, we must have X_k_1'=X_i^N. Following the same logic, X_k_Î²'=X_k_Î²-1^N Â âˆ€Â Î²=2,...,p. For the last element, X_j'^N=X_k_p^N.
	
	Therefore, n_i is forward adjacent to n_k_1, n_k_Î² is forward adjacent to n_k_Î²+1Â âˆ€Â Î²=1,2,...,p-1 and n_k_p is forward adjacent to n_j. Thus, n_i is forward connected to n_j.

sentence:
n_i is said to be forward-connected to n_j if it is possible to go from n_i to n_j by strictly traveling forward . The route for traveling forward from n_i to n_j is denoted as R_iâ†’ j.
	
		The node n_i is forward-adjacent to n_j is the simplest case of n_i being forward connected to n_j. It is obvious that if n_i is forward-connected but not forward-adjacent to n_j, there should exist one or more forward-adjacent nodes n_k_Î² where i<k_Î²<j. Mathematically, in such a case, there will exist nodes n_k_1, n_k_2, ..., n_k_p (1â‰¤ p<j-i) [The inequality 1â‰¤ p<j-i comes because n_i and n_j cannot have more than j-i-1 nodes in between them. Consider n_2 and n_5 for example. The intermediate nodes are n_3 and n_4, so 5-2-1=2. Of course, this number can be less than this. Consider n_10 and n_2 for instance. There are two intermediate nodes: n_3 and n_9 which is less than 10-2-1=7.] such that n_k_Î² is forward-adjacent to n_k_Î²+1Â âˆ€Â 1â‰¤Î²â‰¤ p-1. According to DefinitionÂ <ref>, this implies i<k_1<k_2<...<k_p<j.

sentence:
Let G be a simple graph with n vertices and let L be a list assignment for G.
For each v âˆˆ V(G), let L_v = {v}Ã— L(v).
For each edge uv âˆˆ E(G), let M_uv be a matching (possibly empty) between the sets L_u and L_v, and let _L = {M_uv : uv âˆˆ E(G)}, called the matching assignment .
Let G_L be a graph that satisfies the following conditions:


  * V(G_L) = âˆª_v âˆˆ V(G) L_v,

  * for each v âˆˆ V(G), the set L_v is a clique in G_L,

  * if uv âˆˆ E(G), then the edges between L_u and L_v are exactly those of M_uv, and

  * if uv âˆ‰ E(G), then there are no edges between L_u and L_v.

We say that G has an _L-coloring if G_L contains an independent set of size n.
The graph G is DP-k-colorable if, for any list assignment L with |L(v)| = k for each v âˆˆ V(G), the graph is _L-colorable for every matching assignment _L.
The least k such that G is DP-k-colorable is the DP-chromatic number of G, denoted Ï‡_DP(G).

sentence: We define a three-step layer-stripping operation to be a sequence of boundary edge deletion, isolated boundary vertex deletion, and boundary spike contraction (in that order).  Multiple edges or vertices are allowed to be removed at each step; however, if multiple boundary spikes are contracted, then they are not allowed to share any endpoints with each other.  We allow any one of the three steps to be trivial, and thus a simple layer-stripping operation can be considered a three-step layer-stripping operation.  We allow infinitely many vertices or edges to be removed if the âˆ‚-graph is infinite.

Let P = p_1 p_2 â‹¯ p_m+r and Q = q_1 q_2 â‹¯ q_m+r be two lattice paths 
      from (0,0) to (m, r) with P never going above Q.
      Let { p_u_1, p_u_2, â€¦, p_u_r} be the set of North steps of P, 
      with u_1 < u_2 < â‹¯ < u_r;
      similarly, let { q_l_1, q_l_2, â€¦, q_l_r} be the set of North steps of Q
      with l_1 < l_2 < â‹¯ < l_r.
      Let N_i be the interval [l_i, u_i] of integers.
      Let M(P,Q) be the transversal matroid 
      that has ground set [m+r] and presentation { N_i: i âˆˆ [r] }.
      The pair (P,Q) is a lattice path presentation of M(P,Q).
      A lattice path matroid is a matroidÂ M 
      that is isomorphic to M(P,Q) for some such pair of lattice paths P and Q.
      We will sometimes call a lattice path presentation of M simply a presentation of M
      when there is no danger of confusion and when doing so avoids awkward repetition.

Let x_1, â€¦, x_t âˆˆ N=^2 be non-zero lattice points, and define x_0:=x_t, x_t+1 := x_1. 
We say {x_1, â€¦, x_t} is the set of boundary lattice points P âˆ© N of an l-reflexive loop P of length t if the following three conditions are satisfied for each i=1,â€¦,t:


  * the lattice point x_i+1-x_i is primitive;

  * the determinant of the 2Ã— 2-matrix A_i formed by x_i, x_i+1 equals Â± l;

  * if x_i is a vertex (i.e.Â x_i âˆ‰x_i-1,x_i+1) then it is primitive.

The length of P is defined as âˆ‘_i=1^t (A_i)/l. The set of facets of P is naturally given as the set of line segments between successive vertices. Note that an l-reflexive loop may be a non-convex or self-intersecting polygonal loop (see FigureÂ <ref>).

For i=1, â€¦, t, let u_i be the primitive outer normal to the segment x_i,x_i+1. Then 

    â‹ƒ_i=1^t u_i,u_i+1âˆ© M

is the set of boundary lattice points of the dual l-reflexive loop l P^ (see FigureÂ <ref>). We leave it to the reader to check that this is well-defined and duality as in PropositionÂ <ref> generalizes to this setting.

			zâ‰¤z' in X    if z,z'âˆˆ X,

			f(z)â‰¤z' in Y    if zâˆˆ X and z'âˆˆ Y, or

	The canonical inclusion maps of X and Y into B(f) will be denoted by j_X and j_Y, respectively.

sentence:
Let A be a set of integers and z be an integer. We say that z is covered by A if there exist x,yâˆˆ A such that x<y and 2y-x=z. We frequently say that z is covered by x and y.

Suppose that N is a positive integer. If x,y,zâˆˆ{0,â€¦,N-1} and x y, we say they form an arithmetic progression modulo N, or a mod-AP if 2y-xâ‰¡ z N. 

Suppose again that N is a positive integer and AâŠ†{0,â€¦,N-1}. Then, we say that z is covered by A modulo N , or mod-covered , if there exist x,yâˆˆ A with x<y such that x,y,z form an arithmetic progression modulo N.

[Root class, incoming neighbour, outgoing neighbour]
The vertices of Î¥(U) can be partitioned into subsets according to their roots: for each vertex b of U, let â„›'_b be the set of hyperplanes Hâˆˆâ„›(U) such that b_H=b. Let Hâˆˆâ„›'_b and let V=f(H) be its father.  The hyperplane H'âˆˆâ„›(U) is an incoming neighbour of H if HH' is an edge of Î¥(U) (and in particular H H'), and the iterated imprint IJ(H',U) contains b (and in particular H'â‰º H).

More intuitively, H' is an incoming neighbour of H if HH' is an edge of Î¥(U) and H'â‰º H.  Denote by â„_b(H) the set of incoming neighbours of H.

By LemmaÂ <ref>, for each H'âˆˆâ„_b(H), we have that f(H') contacts a potential father of H that crosses U.  If H' is adjacent to H in Î¥(U) and H' is not an incoming neighbour, then by LemmaÂ <ref>, Hâ‰º H', and we call H' an outgoing neighbour of H.

sentence: An edge-point ribbon graph is an object obtained from a ribbon graph G=(V,E) by contracting  each edge in some (possibly empty) subset B of E to a point. We call the points created by such a process singular points . The image of edges under the contraction that are not singular points are called edges . Its pinched-vertices are components of the images of vertices (including the singular points) under the contraction.

Let k be a natural number, and G be an edge-point ribbon graph. 
A  k-valuation of G_m  is an edge k-colouring of G_m such that each vertex is incident to an even number (possibly zero) of edges of each colour, and all edges incident to a singular vertex are of the same colour.  

If G_m is canonically checkerboard coloured then the four possible configurations of colours about a vertex, are white , black , crossing , or total ,  as described in FigureÂ <ref>. Singular vertices are always total. 
 We let (Ï•) denote the number of non-singular total vertices in a k-valuation Ï•.

then inserting  |l| embedded edges e^*_l,k, k=1,â€¦,|l|, 
respecting the cyclic ordering around v^* and keeping all remaining edges and vertices untouched.
The edges e^*_l,k are incident to v^* and to new vertices v_l,k on c_l.

is the graph with vertex set 
 _1=^* âˆ–(L_h) âˆª{v_l,k}_l âˆˆ L_h and edge 
_1 = ^* âˆ– L_h âˆª{e^*_l,k}_l âˆˆ L_h
obtained after  performing a sequence of grafting operations
 on ^*,  for all   lâˆˆ L_h.

on the setÂ D transitively.

sentence:

        t_i âˆ‰C, and t_iâˆ‰C.

    into t_i in C for each letter z_i âˆˆ I, and by
    reordering if necessary,

        t_i in C for each letter z_i âˆˆ I, and by reordering if
        necessary.

sometimes denote by lCrC.

sentence:
Let there be n cars C_1,â€¦,C_n
of sizes y_1,â€¦,y_n, 
where y_1, â€¦, y_n are positive integers.
Assume there are z-1 + âˆ‘_i=1^n y_i spaces in a row,
where the trailer occupies the z-1 first spaces.
Furthermore, let car C_i have the preferred spotÂ c_i.
Now let the cars
in the orderÂ C_1 through C_n
park according to the following rule:

Starting at position c_i,
car C_i
looks for the first empty spot j â‰¥ c_i.
If the spacesÂ j through j+y_i-1 are empty, then car C_i
parks in these spots.
If any of the spots
j+1 through j+y_i-1 is already occupied,
then there will be a collision, and the result is not a parking sequence.


Iterate this rule for all the cars
C_1, C_2, â€¦, C_n.
We call (c_1,â€¦, c_n) a parking sequence
for yâƒ—=(y_1,â€¦,y_n)
if all n cars can park without any collisions
and without leaving
the z-1 + âˆ‘_i=1^n y_i parking spaces.

In case of a cut, label the two new strands in all possible positive ways of adding the weight of the split edge. Each choice of split produces a distinct monodromy graph.

sentence:
A [NEW stands for New .]  is a 0/1-filling of a Ferrers diagram, possibly with some empty bottom rows, satisfying the following conditions:
  
  
  *  Every column of  has a 1.
  
  *   No four cells of  that form the corners of a rectangle have 0s in two diagonally opposite corners and 1s in the other two.
  
The size of a  is the sum of its number of rows and number of columns.

sentence:
A tree-tableau is a filling of a Ferrers diagram with the following properties:


  * The top left cell has a dot.

  * Every other cell has a dot above it (in the same column) or left of it (in the same row), but not both.

  * Every column and every row has a dot.

The size of a tree-tableau is one less than the sum of its number of rows and number of columns.

sentence: [Polygonal Dissections] A polygonal dissection of a convex n-gon is the union of the polygon and any nonintersecting subset of its diagonals. A d-dissection (respectively, a (d_1,d_2,...,d_r)-dissection ) is a polygonal dissection such that the regions formed by the dissection are all convex (d+1)-gons (respectively, each region is a (d+1)-gon, where dâˆˆ{d_1,d_2,...,d_r}).

sentence:
A quasi-spanning forest is a spanning forest of G with one edge
removed.
The complement of a quasi-spanning forest is a
cut set .[The terms in the literature 
that define quasi-spanning forest and cut set are not 
consistent, for example seeÂ <cit.>,Â <cit.>,Â <cit.>,Â <cit.>.
In some cases, cut sets are called minimal cut sets to indicate that
removing more edges would create more components. In other cases,
cut sets are simply required to disconnect the graph, and the
complement does not even need to be a forest.
Similarly, quasi-spanning forests are often defined only for
connected graphs, in which case they are often named two-trees or
spanning two-trees.
We believe the use of two in this term refers to the number of components,
which will not be two in the generality of disconnected graphs.]

Let C be a polytopal complex. Let S denote a subset of mutually disjoint faces of C. We extend this order to an irreflexive partial order â‰º on C as follows: Let Ïƒ be any face of C, and let Ï„âŠŠÏƒ be any strict face of Ïƒ.

  * If Ï„ is any other face of Ïƒ, then Ïƒ â‰º Ï„.

The transitive closure of the relation â‰º gives an irreflexive partial order on the faces ofÂ C. 

Note that by the correspondence of faces of C to the vertices of C, it gives an irreflexive partial order on _0(  C). Any total order that extends the latter order is a derived order of _0(  C) induced by â‰º.

sentence:
[Star-shaped sets]
A subset X âŠ‚^d is star-shaped if there exists a point x in X, a star-center of X, such that for each y in X, the segment [x,y] lies in X. 
Similarly, a subset X âŠ‚ S^d is star-shaped if X lies in a closed hemisphere of S^d and there exists a star-center x of X, in the interior of the hemisphere containing X, such that for each y in X, the segment from x to y lies in X. With abuse of notation, a polytopal complex C (in ^d or in S^d) is star-shaped if its underlying space is star-shaped.

The transitive closure of the relation â‰º gives an irreflexive partial order on the faces ofÂ C.

[H-splitting derived subdivisions]
Let C be a polytopal complex in â„^d, and let H be a hyperplane of â„^d. An H-splitting derived subdivision of C is a derived subdivision, with vertices chosen so that the following property holds: for any face Ï„ of C that intersects the hyperplane H in the relative interior, the vertex of C that corresponds to Ï„ in C lies on the hyperplane H.

sentence:
[Split link and Lower link]
Let C be a simplicial complex in ^d. Let v be a vertex of C, and let H_+ be a closed halfspace in ^d with outer normal Î½ at vâˆˆ H:=âˆ‚H_+. The split link (of C at v with respect to Î½), denoted by (v, C), is the intersection of (v,  C) with the hemisphere _v^1 H_+, that is, 
    (v, C):= {Ïƒâˆ©_v^1 H_+: Ïƒâˆˆ(v,C)}.

The lower link (v,C) ofÂ C at v with respect to the direction Î½ is the restriction ((v,C), _v^1 H_+) of (v,C) to _v^1 H_+. 

The complex (v, C) is naturally a subcomplex of (v,C): we have as an alternative definition of the lower link the identity 
    (v,C)=((v,C), _v^1 H_+).

sentence:
[Cretan]  
A Cretan matrix, S = (s_ij), of order n, with Ï„ levels, written as Cretan(n;Ï„ ) or CM(n;Ï„;Ï‰), is a Ï„-variable orthogonal matrix, which has had the variables  replaced by real numbers with modulus â‰¤ 1, and CM(n;Ï„;Ï‰ ) and has a least one 1 in each row and column. A CM(n;Ï„), S,  satisfies the orthogonality equation


    S^âŠ¤S = SS^âŠ¤ = Ï‰ I_n,

 
here Ï‰, called the weight , is a  real constant.  

A Cretan matrix is either precisely orthogonal or orthogonal  to (say) 5 decimal places.

[Levels]
The  entries of the Ï„-variable orthogonal matrix of order n, S, are called variables . When the variables are replaced by real numbers/values/entries with modulus â‰¤ 1, and there is at least one 1 in each row and column we have a Cretan(n;Ï„;Ï‰ ) or CM(n;Ï„;Ï‰) which has Ï„ levels.

That is the number of different real numbers, counting plus entries separately from  minus entries, is the number of levels of S.

The level x = 1 is pre-defined for all Cretan matrices.

The orthogonality equation is âˆ‘_j=1^n s_ij^2 =  Ï‰. Ï‰ is called the weight of S.

sentence:
i) An arrangement of pseudolines is a finite set ğ’œ of n â‰¥ 3 smooth closed curves in â„™^2(â„) such that the following conditions are satisfied: 
 
  * Curves in ğ’œ do not intersect themselves.
 
  * Different curves in ğ’œ meet each other transversally in precisely one point.
 
  * We have â‹‚_â„“âˆˆğ’œâ„“ = {}, i.e. ğ’œ is not a pencil arrangement.  
 
Any arrangement ğ’œ induces a cell decomposition of the real projective plane. We denote by ğ’¦(ğ’œ) the set of 2-cells in said decomposition. These are usually called chambers . Similarly, the 1-cells are called edges or segments while the 0-cells are called vertices . We write f^ğ’œ_0, f^ğ’œ_1, f^ğ’œ_2 for the number of vertices, edges, chambers of ğ’œ respectively. Two arrangements ğ’œ, ğ’œ^' are called isomorphic , if the corresponding cell decompositions are isomorphic; in this case, if ğ’œ is an arrangement of straight lines, then ğ’œ^' is called stretchable . 
 
ii) Let ğ’œ be an arrangement of pseudolines in â„™^2(â„). Then ğ’œ is called simplicial if every C âˆˆğ’¦(ğ’œ) is bounded by precisely three lines â„“_1, â„“_2, â„“_3 âˆˆğ’œ.  

iii) Let n:=|ğ’œ| and choose a labelling ğ’œ={â„“_1, â„“_2, ..., â„“_n } for the lines of ğ’œ. We will associate with ğ’œ a geometric lattice L:=L_ğ’œ. For this, define sets L_0, L_1, L_2, L_3  as follows: 
 
  * L_0 consists of the single element {}.
 
  * L_1 consists of the elements { i } for 1 â‰¤ i â‰¤ n.
 
  * For each v âˆˆâ„™^2(â„) we set I_v:={ i | 1 â‰¤ i â‰¤ n,v âˆˆâ„“_i }. Now we define L_2:= { I_v | v âˆˆâ„™^2(â„), |I_v| â‰¥ 2 }  
 
  * L_3 consists of the single element { 1,2, ..., n }.

Now define L:=L_0 âˆª L_1 âˆª L_2 âˆª L_3. It is immediate that L is a poset via setwise inclusion. We have a natural rank function r on L, which is described as follows: r(X)=i if and only if X âˆˆ L_i. Together with this rank function, the poset L becomes a geometric lattice. It is clear that different labellings for the lines of ğ’œ will lead to isomorphic lattices. Therefore, we may define the characteristic polynomial of ğ’œ as the characteristic polynomial of L, i.e. we set Ï‡(ğ’œ,t):=âˆ‘_X âˆˆ LÎ¼({}, X) t^3-(X), where Î¼ denotes the MÃ¶bius Function of L.

sentence:
Let ğ’œ be an arrangement of pseudolines in â„™^2(â„). 

i) For each v âˆˆâ„™^2(â„) we define w_ğ’œ(v):=|{â„“âˆˆğ’œ| v âˆˆâ„“}| âˆˆâ„•_â‰¥ 0 and call it the weight of v (with respect to ğ’œ). Points v âˆˆâ„™^2(â„) such that w_ğ’œ(v)=2 are sometimes called double points (of ğ’œ). Similarly, points v with w_ğ’œ(v)=3 are called triple points (of ğ’œ). Let C âˆˆğ’¦(ğ’œ) be a chamber. We associate with C a graph Î“^C defined as follows: the vertices of Î“^C are given by the lines of ğ’œ which bound C and two vertices â„“, â„“^' are connected by an edge with weight w_ğ’œ(â„“âˆ©â„“^') if and only if w_ğ’œ(â„“âˆ©â„“^') â‰¥ 3.  
 
ii)  For 2 â‰¤ i â‰¤ |ğ’œ| we define t^ğ’œ_i :=| { v âˆˆâ„™^2(â„) | w_ğ’œ(v)=i }|. This means that t^ğ’œ_i is the number of points in â„™^2(â„) contained in precisely i lines of ğ’œ. The vector t^ğ’œâˆˆâ„¤^|ğ’œ|-1 whose i-1-th component is given by t^ğ’œ_i is called the t-vector of ğ’œ. Moreover, if j is maximal with the property t^ğ’œ_j>0, then we say that the multiplicity of ğ’œ is j and we write m(ğ’œ):=j.    

iii) Assume that n:=|ğ’œ| â‰¥ 3. If ğ’œ is an arrangement such that t^ğ’œ_2=n-1 and t^ğ’œ_n-1=1 then ğ’œ is called a near pencil (arrangement) . Near pencil arrangements are usually considered trivial.

Let F be a 4-regular graph, and P a partition of the edge-set
of F into edge-disjoint circuits. The touch-graph Tch(P) is the

corresponding to circuits of P that are incident at v.

sentence:
[Theorem 1.5 of <cit.>] 
The following three conditions about a cluster algebra ğ’œ = ğ’œ(ğ±_0,B_0) are equivalent:



  * Cluster algebra ğ’œ is of finite type.

  * In every seed (ğ±,B) that is mutation-equivalent to (ğ±_0,B_0), the exchange matrix B satisfies |b_ij b_ji| â‰¤ 3 for all pairs 1 â‰¤ i, j â‰¤ n.

  * There exists a mutation-equivalent seed (ğ±_1,B_1) such that the exchange matrix B_1 is a skew-symmetric version of a Cartan matrix of a finite-dimensional Lie algebra[
Given a Cartan matrix A, we make a skew-symmetric B_A by replacing the 2's on the diagonal with 0's, and picking a bipartite coloring of the Dynkin diagram associated to A so that b_ij = |a_ij| if directed edge v_i â†’ v_j would go from white to black, and b_ij = - |a_ij| otherwise, see SectionÂ <ref>.].

In particular, cluster algebras of finite type are given by the same Cartan-Killing classification as that describing Lie algebras via Dynkin diagrams: 
    A_n, Â B_n,Â  C_n,Â  D_n,Â  E_6,Â  E_7,Â  E_8,Â  F_4,Â andÂ  G_2.

sentence:

  * ğ’œ is of finite mutation type,
 
  * In every seed (ğ±,B) that is mutation-equivalent to (ğ±_0,B_0), the exchange matrix B satisfies |b_ij b_ji| â‰¤ 4 for all pairs 1 â‰¤ i, j â‰¤ n.

sentence:
[Skew-symmetrizable matrices]
  An n-by-n matrix B is called skew-symmetrizable if there exists a diagonal integer matrix D with strictly positive entries on the diagonal such that DB is skew-symmetric.

sentence:
[Labeled Seed for a cluster algebra]
A labeled seed for a cluster algebra ğ’œ = ğ’œ(ğ±,ğ²,B) is a triple (ğ±, ğ², B) where


 
  * ğ± = {x_0,x_1,â€¦, x_n-1} is a cluster of n algebraically independent elements of ambient field â„±,

 
  * ğ² = {y_0,y_1,â€¦, y_n-1} is an n-tuple of coefficients, elements of the semifield â„™, and 

 
  * B is an n-by-n matrix that is skew-symmetrizable.

sentence:
[Cluster Algebras of Geometric Type]
A cluster algebra of geometric type is one where the coefficient semifield â„™ is a special choice which leads to a great simplification of the above formulas.  In this case,

    â„™= Trop(u_0,u_1,u_2,â€¦, u_m-1)

where the addition âŠ• in Trop(u_0,u_1,u_2,â€¦, u_m-1) is defined as 
    âˆ_j u_j^a_jâŠ•âˆ_j u_j^b_j = âˆ_j u_j^min(a_j,b_j).
  In particular, note that if y_i = âˆ_j u_j^a_j where all a_j â‰¥ 0, then y_i âŠ• 1 = 1.  With â„™ given as this tropical semifield, the group ring â„¤â„™ is simply the ring of Laurent polynomials â„¤[u_0^Â± 1, u_1^Â± 1, â€¦, u_m-1^Â± 1].

sentence:
[Principal coefficients]
An important cluster algebra of geometric type is one with principal coefficients .  In this case, the initial exchange matrix B is 2n-by-n and where the last n rows of this matrix is a rank n identity matrix.

sentence: A quiver Q is a directed graph.  We will only work with quivers on a finite number of vertices and which contains no loops (1-cycles) or 2-cycles.  However, we do allow our quivers to have multiple edges between a pair of vertices, but since there are no 2-cycles, this means that all edges between two vertices must have the same direction.  In general there is no restriction against oriented cycles on â‰¥ 3 vertices.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
[Constructing a pair-weighted quiver from an exchange matrix]
To get a quiver Q_B from an (m+n)-by-n exchange matrix B is the reverse of the above construction, however, there are two nuances to emphasize.




  * For a cluster algebra seed to correspond to a quiver, the corresponding matrix B must satisfy b_ij = - b_ji for all pairs 0 â‰¤ i,jâ‰¤ n-1.  In other words, the top n-by-n portion of B must be skew-symmetric, not just skew-symmetrizable.  Since cluster algebras for non-skew-symmetric seeds are also quite prevalent in the literature, our package works with a slight generalization of quivers, which we call pair-weighted quivers .  

We do not allow parallel edges in such quivers, and instead, we label each directed edge as an ordered pair [b_ij, b_ji] such that the associated edge is oriented from v_i to v_j.  Consequently, the first entry of each such pair is necessarily positive and the second is negative, but the direction of the edge must also be recorded.  In the case that b_ji = -b_ij, i.e. the case of parallel edges, this label is simplified to be simply the positive number b_ij.  We also omit the label b_ij=1 when displaying graphics to make pictures easier to view.  

Note, that this notation differs from that in places such as <cit.> or <cit.>, but is necessarily for precise computations.  Our notation is inspired by Dlab-Ringel <cit.> and Dupont-PÃ©rotin <cit.>.


  * If m > 0, i.e. the matrix has more rows than columns, and for any b_ij where i â‰¥ n, there is no b_ji in the matrix and so we do not have to worry about checking skew-symmetry for such entries.  However, such vertices v_i correspond to a frozen variable and so we designate these vertices accordingly as â€œfrozen verticesâ€ to remind the user not to mutate or apply exchanges at such vertices.

[Mutation-equivalence]
   Two quivers Q_1, Q_2 are said to be mutation-equivalent if one can be obtained from the other by a finite sequence of mutations, i.e., if there exists a finite sequence i_1,â€¦,i_k such that Î¼_i_kâˆ˜â€¦âˆ˜Î¼_i_1(Q_1) = Q_2. The collection of all quivers mutation-equivalent to a given quiver Q is called mutation class of Q.

sentence:
[Generalized Cartan matrix]
  An n Ã— n-matrix A = (a_ij) with integer entries is called a generalized Cartan matrix if
  
    
  * a_ii = 2,
    
  * a_ij < 0 for i â‰  j,
    
  * A is symmetrizable, i.e., there exists a diagonal matrix D with positive entries such that DA is symmetric.
  
  A generalized Cartan matrix is called of finite type if DA is positive definite, and of affine type if DA is positive semi-definite.

sentence:
[Generalized associahedron]
 The generalized associahedron associated to a cluster algebra ğ’œ can be defined as the exchange graph of the mutation class of all cluster seeds for ğ’œ. This is the unoriented graph with vertices given by the set of all cluster seeds, and with an edge joining two clusters if they can be obtained from each other by a mutation.

[Cluster complex]
 The cluster complex associated to a cluster algebra ğ’œ can be defined to be the simplicial complex with vertices being the cluster variables for ğ’œ and with facets being the clusters.

sentence:
An orientable surface-link in â„^4 is unknotted if it is equivalent to a surface embedded in â„^3Ã—{0}âŠ‚â„^4. A marked graph diagram for an unknotted standard sphere is shown in Fig. <ref>(a), an unknotted standard torus is in Fig. <ref>(d). An embedded projective plane â„™^2 in â„^4 is unknotted if it is equivalent to a surface whose marked graph diagram is an unknotted standard projective plane , which looks like in Fig. <ref>(b) that is a positive â„™^2_+ or looks like in Fig. <ref>(c) that is a negative â„™^2_-. These are inequivalent surfaces and are mirror images to one another. A non-orientable surface embedded in â„^4 is unknotted if it is equivalent to some finite connected sum or split unions of unknotted projective planes.

By a standard surface-unlink marked diagram we mean the diagram obtained by taking connected sums or split unions (in the plane) of the standard sphere or the standard tori or the standard projective plane diagrams.

sentence:
[<cit.>]
  A graph G is a wheel if there is a vertex v of degree
  at least 3 such that G-v is isomorphic to a cycle. The vertex
  v is the center of the wheel and the subgraph G-v is the
  rim of the wheel. A wheel is a 3-wheel if there are
  three consecutive vertices x,y,z on the rim such that the center
  is adjacent to x, y, and z.

sentence:
We define a set of operations called switch operations . Each operation
takes a pattern p and breaks it down into two parts by the largest letter n.
The first part contains the part of the pattern p that appears before n. The
second part contains the part of p that appears after n. Then one of the two
operations, ğ•€,r, is used on each part, where (Ï„, R)^ğ•€ = (Ï„, R).
After that theses parts can be switched, i.e., part two will then appear before
n and part one after n. An operation will be denoted as S_a,b,d, Where
a is the operation used on part one and b the operation used on part two.
The letter d is 1 if part one and two are switched and 0 otherwise. These
switch operations can also be used on permutations.

sentence:
Let M be a matroid on a linearly ordered set E.
Let B be a basis of M. 
The active filtration of B is the unique (connected) filtration of M associated to B by Theorem <ref>.

ÃŸ

For what follows in the paper, we only need the above definition. 


Two other equivalent definitions are available, they are constructive and based on the fundamental graph of the basis only. The active filtration of B can be defined:



=0mm =0mm =0mm =0mm

  * by applying successively the active closure to the internal/external active elements, see <cit.>;

  * by a single pass algorithm over E, see <cit.>, which is used (and formally contained) in next Theorem <ref>.

The active partition of B is the partition of E induced by successive differences of subsets in the active filtration of B, given with the cyclic flat F_c of the filtration
(so that the active filtration of B is determined, as observed above).

The active minors of B are the minors induced by the active filtration of B.

sentence: For J, J' âˆˆ[2k-1]k-1, we say that J' is a swap of J if J âˆ© J' = âˆ…. Clearly the relation of being a swap is symmetric. If J and J' are swaps of one another, there is a unique element j^* âˆˆ [2k-1] âˆ– (J âˆª J') and we callÂ j^* their pivot . We say J' is a balanced swap of J if it is a swap of J and their pivot j^* is such that |J âˆ© [j^*]| = |J' âˆ© [j^*]|. We say that that J' is a end swap of J if it is a swap of J and their pivot j^* is either 1 or 2k-1. Observe thatÂ J' being an end swap of J implies it is a balanced swap of J. Define bswap(J) (resp. eswap(J)) to be the set of balanced swaps (resp. end swaps) of J.

* A ((2k+1)-orthogonal ) vacillating tableau of length r is a sequence of partitions âˆ…=Î¼^0, Î¼^1,â€¦,Î¼^r=Î¼ each of at most k parts, such that:


  * Î¼^i and Î¼^i+1 differ in at most one position,

  * Î¼^i=Î¼^i+1 only occurs if the k^th part of both partitions is non-empty.

We call the final partition Î¼ the shape of the tableau.

  * A ((2k+1)-orthogonal ) highest weight word is a word w with letters in {Â± 1, Â± 2, â€¦, Â± k, 0} of length r such that for every initial segment s of w the following holds (we write #i for the number of i's in s):


  * #i - #(-i) â‰¥ 0,

  * #i-#(-i)â‰¥#(i+1)-#(-i-1),

  * if the last letter is 0 then #k-#(-k)>0.

We call the partition (#1-#(-1),#2-#(-2),â€¦, #k - #(-k)) the weight of a highest weight word. The vacillating tableau corresponding to a word w is the sequence of weights of the initial segments of w.


By abuse of terminology we refer to both objects as vacillating tableaux .

The vertices are pairs of tableaux (T,C) where T is a two-column skew semistandard Young tableau and C is a column strict single column such that:


  * The tail of a two-column skew semistandard tableau is the part of the tableau where only the first column exists. We require that the tail of T have length Î¼_1.

  * The residuum of a two-column skew semistandard tableau is the number of positions we can shift the second column down such that the result is still a skew semistandard tableau. We require that the residuum of T be less than or equal to 1.

To obtain the edges, we consider this as a subgraph of the tensor product of 3=2k+1 one-column crystal graphs. Note that taking this point of view Ï†_i(b_â„“)âˆˆ{1,0} for â„“=1,2,3.

We obtain the concatenation Q of two standard Young tableaux Q_1 and Q_2 in the following way. First we add the largest entry of Q_1 to each entry of Q_2 to obtain the tableau Q_2. Then we append the i^th row Q_2 to the i^th row of Q_1 to obtain Q.

The concatenation of two vacillating tableaux is obtained by concatenating the words.

sentence:
Let G be the planar map obtained by taking the union of all
  vertices and edges that either lie in the sequence from
  LemmaÂ <ref> or on the boundary of a face in this
  sequence. We call this subgraph of T the girdle with
  respect to Ï†. Its cells from the cyclic sequence are called
  central cells of G, the other ones (which are only part of
  G because they lie on the boundary of a face from the sequence)
  are called outer cells of G. By construction, every face in
  the sequence is also a face of G (and hence a central cell); the
  other faces of G are called its sides . For every face in
  the sequence, precisely one of the edges on its boundary is a
  central cell and so is the other face incident with this edge. The
  union of such two faces and their boundaries is called a
  diamond . Note that every girdle has at least two central
  vertices; let j(G) be the smallest index for which c_j(G) is a
  vertex.

    is pseudo-antarctic).
  
  The fyke net of T with respect to the group

  The intersection of the fyke net with the level F_i is
  its ith layer and denoted by H_i. Note that every layer
  is a plane symmetric cactus of order m by the symmetry of the

  * faces that are bounded by cycles in a branch of a layer; we
    call such faces leaves ;
  
  * faces bounded by two consecutive  and two
    subpaths of the two layers connecting their sources and their
    targets; we call such faces segments ;
  
  * if the last layer H_k is pseudo-antarctic, m faces that
    are bounded by a subpath of the centre of H_k and the south pole
    c_1 (if it is an edge) or one of its incident edges (if it is a
    face); we call such faces pseudo-antarctic ;
  
  * the south pole c_1 (if it is a face).

  Î±(D_C).

	it holds
	(
		Q_j =  j+t âˆ‰{i_1,â€¦,i_k}).

	{i_1,â€¦,i_k}âŠ†{0,â€¦,m-1}	
	of k errors is detected by Q at some position tâˆˆ{0,â€¦,â„“}.

Let k be a positive integer, B be a graph, and (B,d_B) a k-partial distance graph of B. For an edge xy with d_B(xy)=p, we say that a k-good triple {p,q,r} is realized on xy if there are two vertices z_1 and z_2 of B with d_B(x,z_1)=q, d_B(y,z_1)=r, d_B(x,z_2)=r and d_B(y,z_2)=q.
We say that (B,d_B) has the all k-good triple property if E(B)â‰ âˆ…, and for each edge xy and each k-good triple T = {p,q,r} with p=d_B(x,y), T is realized on xy.

sentence:
[Intersection graphs]
A feature system is a triple (V, Î©, f), where V is a set of vertices, Î© is a set of features , and f is a function mapping vertices in V to subsets of Î©. Given a vertex vâˆˆ V, we call f(v)âŠ†Î© its feature set . We construct a graph G on the vertex-set V from a feature system (V, Î©, f) by placing an edge between u,v âˆˆ V if their feature sets f(u), f(v) have non-empty intersection. We call G the intersection graph of the feature system (V, Î©,f).

A maximal inflated hairpin in an L & P matching is two sets of edges A={a_1,a_2,â€¦,a_k} and B={b_1,b_2,â€¦,b_â„“} such that

sentence: (Ehrhart's Theorem) If P is a convex polytope whose vertices have rational coordinates, then the number of points with integer coordinates in the dilations NP for N = 0, 1, 2 â€¦ is a quasi-polynomial in N whose degree is the dimension of P and whose period divides the least common multiple of the denominators of the vertices of P.

sentence:
[Rational equivalence and Chow groups]
Let C be an (abstract) cycle. Let R(C):={(|C|,h)| h  bounded}âŠ†Div(C) be the subgroup of Cartier divisors on C globally given by a bounded rational function and

    Pic(C):=Div(C)/R(C)

be the Picard group of C, where pull-backs induced by pull-backs of Cartier divisors are well-defined. Let D,D' be subcycles of C. We call D rationally equivalent to zero on C if there exists a cycle C' of dimension dim(D)+1, a morphism f:C'â†’ C and a bounded rational function hâˆˆ R(C') such that

    f_*(hÂ· C')=D.

We call D and D' rationally equivalent (notation: D âˆ¼ D') if D-D' is rationally equivalent to zero. The k-th Chow group of C is defined as

    A_k(C):=Z_k(C)/âˆ¼,

where the intersection product Z_n-k(â„^n)Ã— Z_n-l(â„^n)â†’ Z_n-k-l(â„^n) induces a well-defined bilinear map (proposition 1.8.10 of <cit.>)

    A_n-k(â„^n)Ã— A_n-l(â„^n)    â†’ A_n-k-l(â„^n)
    
    ([E],[F])    â†¦ [E]Â· [F]:=[EÂ· F].

sentence:
[Degree]
Let |Î”|âˆˆâ„•_>0. A set Î”:={ (v_i,x_i)}_i=1,â€¦,|Î”| of tuples is called degree if


  (1)
0â‰  v_iâˆˆâ„^2 for all i=1,â€¦,|Î”|, and âŸ¨ v_1,â€¦,v_|Î”|âŸ©=â„^2, and âˆ‘_i v_i=0.

  (2)
x_iâˆˆâ„•_>0 for all i=1,â€¦,|Î”|, and x_iâ‰  x_j for all iâ‰  j. An x_i is called label .

Let Î£ be a 2-dimensional lattice polytope in â„^2 with facets E_1,â€¦,E_m whose lattice lengths are denoted by |E_1|,â€¦,|E_m| and let e_1,â€¦,e_m be unordered partitions of E_1,â€¦,E_m, that is e_i is a partition of E_i of some length denoted by l(e_i) for i=1,â€¦,m. If

    { v_i }_i=1,â€¦,|Î”|=â‹ƒ_i=1^mâ‹ƒ_j=1^l(e_i){ e_i_jÂ·pnv(E_i) },

where pnv(E_i) is the primitive normal vector of E_i^âŠ¥ for i=1,â€¦,m, then Î” is said to be associated to a polytope Î£ with partitions e_1,â€¦,e_m and is referred to as Î”( Î£(e_1,â€¦,e_m)).

Important special cases that we use later are the following:


  * If each entry of each partition e_i is one, then the associated degree is denoted by Î”(Î£).

  * In case of degree d curves in â„™^2, the degree Î” is defined as follows:
Let Î£_d be the convex hull of { (0,0),(d,0),(d,0)}âˆˆâ„^2 for some dâˆˆâ„•_>0, then Î”_d is the degree associated to Î£_d, where the labels are given by: vectors parallel to (and with the same direction as) (-1,0)âˆˆâ„^2 have labels 1,â€¦,d, vectors parallel to (and with the same direction as) (0,-1) have labels d+1,â€¦,2d and vectors parallel to (and with the same direction as) (1,1) have labels 2d+1,â€¦,3d.

  * In case of degree (|Î±|,|Î²|) curves of contact orders Î±,Î² in the first Hirzebruch surface, the degree Î” is defined as follows:
Let sâˆˆâ„•_>0 and bâˆˆâ„•. Let Î±=(Î±_1,â€¦) be an unordered partition of b+s, let Î²=(Î²_1,â€¦) be an unordered partition of b and let Î£(Î±,Î²) be the convex hull of { (0,0),(s,0),(s,b),(0,b+s)}âˆˆâ„^2. We associate the degree Î”(Î±,Î²) to the polytope Î£(Î±,Î²), where the partition of the left facet is given by Î± and the partition of the right facet is given by Î². Moreover, vectors parallel to (and with the same direction as) (-1,0)âˆˆâ„^2 have labels 1,â€¦, l(Î±), vectors parallel to (and with the same direction as) (1,0) have labels l(Î±)+1,â€¦,l(Î±)+l(Î²).

[Free and fixed components]
Let C be a rational tropical curve (possibly with vertices of higher valence) that is fixed by general positioned points p_1,â€¦,p_n. Let v be an m-valent vertex of C such that there is no point lying on v and denote adjacent edges of v by e_1,â€¦,e_m. Fix iâˆˆ{ 1,â€¦,m}, cut the edge e_i and stretch it to infinity. Now there are two tropical curves, namely one that contains v and one that does not. The tropical curve C_i that does not contain v is called a component of v . A component of v is called a fixed component of v if it is fixed by the points on it (if this component is only a line, then this line is considered fixed if there is a point on it). Otherwise it is called a free component of v .

[Minkowski labeled polytopes]
Let P be the Minkowski sum of a labeled polytope PÌƒâŠ‚â„^2 that is either 0-dimensional or 2-dimensional and segments S_1,â€¦,S_r such that each segment is parallel to an edge of PÌƒ and P is 2-dimensional. Note that if PÌƒ is a point, then every segment is by definition parallel to it. Moreover, we require that if PÌƒ is 0-dimensional, then there are two segments S_i_1,S_i_2âˆˆ{ S_1,â€¦, S_r} such that all other Minkowski summands of P are parallel to one of them. Let E be an edge of P and denote by F_1,â€¦,F_k edges of the Minkowski summands PÌƒ,S_1,â€¦,S_r that contribute to E. If Ï„^F_i is the labeling of F_i, then we define Ï„^E to be the multiset

    Ï„^E:=Ï„^F_1â€¦Ï„^F_k.

A pair ( P,Ï„) of such a polytope P with e edges E^1,â€¦,E^e and a tuple of multisets Ï„=( Ï„^E^1,â€¦,Ï„^E^e), where Ï„^E^i is defined above, together with maps that match labels to the summands they come from

    f_P|_E:Ï„^E â†’{PÌƒ,S_1,â€¦,S_r }

such that if f_P|_E(t)=Aâˆˆ{PÌƒ,S_1,â€¦,S_r }, then tâˆˆÏ„^F_i for F_iâŠ‚ A, is called a Minkowski labeled polytope .

  * A Minkowski labeled poyltope P is called k-marked if PÌƒ has e edges E^j with labelings Ï„^j such that âˆ‘_j=1^e |Ï„^j|=3+k holds, where |Ï„^j|âˆˆâ„•_>0 is the number of entries of Ï„^j. If k=0 or PÌƒ is 0-dimensional, then P is called unmarked .


  * A Minkowski labeled polytope is called valid polytope if it is either unmarked or k-marked. Two valid polytopes that share an edge E are compatible if their labelings of E coincide.

  * Let PÌƒ be a 1-dimensional polytope where each side of its edge E is equipped with a labeling. The Minkowski sum of PÌƒ with segments S_1,â€¦,S_r parallel to it, where each summand contributes a label to the two labelings of E as in definition <ref> is called a pointed segment . If PÌƒ is 0-dimensional, then it is called a non-pointed segment (all S_i are then parallel). The notion of compatibility extends to (non-)pointed segments as well: If a valid polytope and a (non-)pointed segment share an edge, then they are compatible if their labelings on this (side of the) edge coincide. We can refer to a (non-)pointed segment as k-marked as above.

sentence:
[Coloring]
A coloring of a labeled polytope P is a 2-coloring of all of its labels on each of its edges. 
The two colors are called fixed and free . A colored polytope is called free (or fixed ) if it is monochromatic of the color free (or fixed). Given a colored Minkowski labeled polytope P, we say that exactly PÌƒ is fixed if all labels associated to PÌƒ are colored fixed and the rest is colored free.

The other polytopes in ğ’œ\{ P_i_1,â€¦,P_i_n} are non-pointed segments that are colored free. The set ğ’œ is called a cross-ratio lattice path if the following conditions are satisfied:

[Cross-ratio floor diagrams]
Let dâˆˆâ„•_>0 and let â„± be a tree on a totally ordered set of vertices v_1,â€¦,v_n, then â„± is called a cross-ratio floor diagram of degree Î”_d if:

Each vertex v is labeled with s_v,|Î»_v|âˆˆâ„• and a set Î´_v of labels that appear in Î”_d, where |Î»_v| is called the number of cross-ratios of v and s_v is called the size of v such that 

    s_v={ xâˆˆÎ´_v| d+1â‰¤ xâ‰¤ 2d } = { xâˆˆÎ´_v| 2d+1â‰¤ xâ‰¤ 3d }

and âˆ…=Î´_vâˆ©Î´_v' for all vâ‰  v' and â‹ƒ_v Î´_v  is the set of all labels appearing in Î”_d.

  (3)
The number of thick edges adjacent to a vertex v is 2-2s_v+|Î»_v|.

  (4)
The total ordering on the vertices induces directions on the edges in the following way: we order the vertices on a line starting with the smallest vertex v_1 on the left and direct the edges from smaller to larger vertices. Each edge e of the graph is equipped with a weight Ï‰(e)âˆˆâ„• such that the balancing condition

holds for all vertices v, where the sign is + for outgoing edges and - for incoming edges of v.

Let â„± be a cross-ratio floor diagram of degree Î”_d on the ordered set of vertices v_1,â€¦,v_n corresponding to given point conditions p_1,â€¦,p_n such that â„±satisfies the degenerated cross-ratios Î»_1,â€¦,Î»_l. The  i-th piece (â„±_i,Î´_v_i,s_v_i,|Î»_v_i|,Î»Ìƒ_i_1,â€¦,Î»Ìƒ_i_|Î»_v_i|) (for i=1,â€¦,n) of â„± is obtained from â„± in the following way: Cut all edges that connect the vertex v_i to other vertices of â„± into (thick or thin) half-edges, and call the connected component containing v_i now â„±_i, equip the cut edges with the labels indicating the vertices that they used to be connected to.

sentence:
Let G be a 4-critical graph, RâŠŠ V(G) with |R|â‰¥ 4 and Ï• be a 3-coloring of G[R]. Now let W be a 4-critical subgraph of G_Ï•(R) and T be the triangle corresponding to R in G. Then we say that R' = (W-T)âˆª R is a critical extension of R with extender W. We refer to Wâˆ© T as the core of the extension.

If a vertex in W-T has more neighbors in R then in X or there exists an edge in G[V(W-T)] that is not in W-T, then we say that the extension is incomplete . Otherwise, we say the extension is complete . If R'=V(G), then we say the extension is spanning . A total extension is an extension that is both complete and spanning.

sentence:
Let G be a graph and RâŠŠ V(G) with |R|â‰¥ 2. The boundary of R is the set of vertices in R with neighbors in Gâˆ– R. If G is 4-critical, we say R is collapsible if in every 3-coloring of G[R] all vertices in the boundary of R receive the same color. If R is collapsible, then we define the critical complement of R to be the graph obtained by identifying the boundary of R to one vertex v and deleting the rest of R. We call v the collapsed vertex of W.

Note then that the boundary of R is an independent set and for any u,v in the boundary of R, G[R]+uv contains a 4-critical subgraph. We say a collapsible subset is tight if for any u,v in the boundary of R, G[R]+uv is 4-critical.

sentence: Let v be a vertex of degree three in G_0 with neighbors u_1,u_2,u_3. If u_1 is not adjacent to u_2 then the graph obtained from G_0 by deleting v and identifying u_1 and u_2 is not 3-colorable and so contains a 4-critical subgraph K. We say K is a degree three reduction of v in the direction of u_1 and u_2 and denote it by K(v; u_1,u_2). We also say that K is a degree three reduction of v away from u_3 and may denote it as K(v;u_3). We say R=V(K)-u_1u_2 + {v,u_1,u_2} is the expansion of K.

sentence:
We can now specify the data for the reconstruction problem for Sperner systems.
The objects are all Sperner systems over finite sets.
The equivalence is given by the isomorphism between Sperner systems.
The size of a Sperner system is the cardinality of its ground set.
For each n âˆˆâ„•, the index set I_n is the set  of all two-element subsets of n.
We may assume that we have, for every finite set A, a fixed bijection Ïƒ_A Aâ†’ A.
Then for a Sperner system  over a set A of cardinality n and for I âˆˆ, the derived object _I is ^*_Ïƒ_A(I).
Hence the cards of a Sperner system  over A are the isomorphism types ^*_I / â‰¡ of the Sperner systems ^*_I for I âˆˆ[A], and the deck of  is the multiset {^*_I / â‰¡ : I âˆˆ[A]}.

sentence:
We can now specify the data for the reconstruction problem for functions of several arguments and identification minors.
The objects are all functions of several arguments from A to B, i.e., the elements of the set F_AB.
The equivalence relation is the relation â‰¡ on F_AB as defined above.
The size of a function f  A^n â†’ B is its arity n.
For each n âˆˆâ„•, the index set I_n is the set  of all two-element subsets of n.
For a function f  A^n â†’ B and for I âˆˆ, the derived object f_I is the identification minor f_I of f as defined above.
Hence the cards of f are the equivalence classes f_I / â‰¡ of the various identification minors f_I of f, and the deck of f is the multiset {f_I / â‰¡ : I âˆˆ}.

sentence:
Let X, Y âŠ†m with X âˆ© Y = âˆ…, and let Z := mâˆ– (X âˆª Y).

The full signature (X,Y) of (X,Y) is the string d_1 â€¦ d_m over the alphabet {x, y, z} defined by

    d_i =
    
    x,    if i âˆˆ X,
    
    y,    if i âˆˆ Y,
    
    z,    if i âˆˆ Z.


Define the map Ïˆ{x, y, z}^* âˆ–{z}^* â†’{x, y, Î±, Î²}^* as follows: Ïˆ maps any string d_1 â€¦ d_n that does not comprise entirely of z's to the unique string d'_1 â€¦ d'_n satisfying the following conditions (we do addition modulo n, so that d_0 = d_n):


  * if d_i âˆˆ{x, y}, then d'_i = d_i;

  * if d_i = z, then d'_i âˆˆ{Î±, Î²} and d'_i â‰  d'_i-1;

  * if d_i = z and d_i-1 = x, then d'_i = Î²;

  * if d_i = z and d_i-1 = y, then d'_i = Î±.

Define the map Ï†{x, y, Î±, Î²}^* â†’ğ’«({Î±, Î²}) as follows:

    Ï†(d_1 â€¦ d_n) = {e âˆˆ{Î±, Î²} : #_e(d_1 â€¦ d_n) is odd}.

In order to simplify notation, we will write the possible values of Ï† as âˆ…, Î±, Î², and Î±Î² instead of âˆ…, {Î±}, {Î²}, and {Î±, Î²}.

sentence:
The reconstruction problem for hypergraphs and vertex-deleted subhypergraphs comprises the following data.
The objects are all hypergraphs with a finite vertex set.
The equivalence is given by the isomorphism between hypergraphs.
The size of a hypergraph is the number of its vertices.
For each n âˆˆâ„•, the index set I_n is n. We may assume that there is a fixed bijection between n and any n-element set, and we identify each element of n with its image under this bijection.
For each hypergraph G and v âˆˆ V(G), the derived object G_v is the vertex-deleted hypergraph G - v whose vertex set is V(G) âˆ–{v} and edge set is {e âˆˆ E(G) : v âˆ‰ e}.
Hence the cards of a hypergraph G are the isomorphism types (G - v) / â‰¡ of the vertex-deleted hypergraphs G - v for v âˆˆ V(G), and the deck of G is the multiset {(G - v) / â‰¡ : v âˆˆ V(G)}.

sentence:
<cit.>
A signed graph is a set of vertices, together with a set of positive edges, negative edges, and loops connecting them. A positive edge (resp. negative edge ) is an edge between two vertices, labelled with a + ( resp. with a -). A loop connects a vertex to itself; we regard it as a negative edge. There is at most one positive and one negative edge connecting a pair of vertices, and there is at most one loop connecting a vertex to itself.

sentence:
A signed graph G is connected if and only if its underlying graph G (ignoring signs) is connected. The connected components of G correspond to those of G. A cycle in G corresponds to a cycle of G; we call it balanced if it contains an even number of negative edges, and unbalanced otherwise. We say that G is balanced if all its cycles

are balanced.

sentence:
A cycle of a signed graph is positive if the sign product of its edges is positive, or the number of its negative edges is even.  In the opposite case it is negative .  
A signed graph is balanced if all its cycles are positive; e.g., if it is cycle free (i.e., a forest).

sentence: Switching a signed graph means reversing the signs of all edges between a vertex subset W âŠ† V and its complement, V-W.  (The negated edge set may be void.)  We note that switching does not change the sign of a closed chain.

sentence:
In a signed graph G_Ïƒ, a block is an inner block if it is unbalanced or it contains an edge of a path connecting two balanced blocks.  In the opposite case it is an outer block .

An unbalanced necklace of balanced blocks is a signed graph constructed from balanced signed blocks B_1Ïƒ_1, B_2Ïƒ_2, â€¦, B_kÏƒ_k (kâ‰¥2) and distinct vertices v_i, w_i âˆˆ B_iÏƒ_i by identifying v_i with w_i-1 for i=2,â€¦,k and v_1 with w_k.  The blocks B_iÏƒ_i are called the constituents of the necklace.  Note that an unbalanced necklace of balanced blocks is an unbalanced block.

A core of G_Ïƒ is the union of inner blocks of an unbalanced connected component of G_Ïƒ.

sentence:
Let G_Ïƒ be a signed graph and let P be a chain (not necessarily elementary) connecting x and y in G_Ïƒ:

    P: x,e_1,x_1,e_2,x_2,â€¦,y.

where x,x_1,â€¦,y âˆˆ V and e_1,e_2,â€¦âˆˆ E.
We put 

    Ïƒ(P)=âˆ_e_iâˆˆ PÏƒ(e_i)âˆˆ{-1,+1}
 
and we call P positive (resp., negative ) if Ïƒ(P)=+1 (resp., Ïƒ(P)=-1).  
(This sign rule generalizes the sign of a cycle.)

We may write P^Îµ instead of P when Îµ=Ïƒ(P) and we may write P^Îµ(x, y) when P is a chain connecting x and y.
P^Îµ is called an Îµ-chain of sign Îµ .

The graph of a chain P is G(P), the subgraph of G_Ïƒ that consists of all the vertices and edges of P.

An Îµ-chain P^Îµ(x,y) is elementary if it is minimal given its sign and its end vertices.  
Minimality means that no other Îµ-chain that connects x and y has a graph that is a proper subgraph of G(P^Îµ(x,y)).

sentence:
Let G_Ïƒ= (V, E ;Ïƒ) be a signed graph. Let us consider the relation R in V defined by:

    x R y â‡”
       
            x = y ,  or
    there exist both a negative chain and a positive chain joining x and y.

Then R is an equivalence relation whose equivalence classes form a partition {V_1,â€¦, V_q} of V. If xRy, we say x and y are sign connected .  The subgraphs of G_Ïƒ generated by the subsets V_i (i= 1, â€¦, q) are  called the sign-connected components of G_Ïƒ.

A signed graph is called sign connected if it has just one sign-connected component; that is, for any pair of vertices x and y, there exist both a positive chain and a negative chain connecting them.

sentence:
[<cit.>]
A signed graph G_Ïƒ=(V,E; Ïƒ) has associated two matroids, the frame matroid M(G_Ïƒ) and the lift matroid L(G_Ïƒ). A definition of M(G_Ïƒ) is that a subset F âŠ† E is a circuit of M(G_Ïƒ ) (a frame circuit of G_Ïƒ) if either


  * F is a positive cycle,

  * or F is the union of two negative cycles having exactly one common vertex,

  * or F is the union of two vertex-disjoint negative cycles and an elementary chain which connects the cycles and is internally disjoint from both cycles.



  

  
    < g r a p h i c s >

  

   We represent a positive (resp., negative) cycle by a quadrilateral (resp., triangle).
   


A definition of L(G_Ïƒ) is that a subset F âŠ† E is a circuit of L(G_Ïƒ ) (a lift circuit of G_Ïƒ) if it is of type (i), (ii), or 


  Type (iii'): F is the union of two vertex-disjoint negative cycles.

It is called lift connected if L(G_Ïƒ) is connected or if G_Ïƒ = K_1.

sentence:
The connected components of M(G_Ïƒ) induce subgraphs of G_Ïƒ, which are called frame components of G_Ïƒ ( M-components in <cit.>). Thus, a frame component of G_Ïƒ is a maximal subgraph without isolated vertices whose frame matroid is connected, or it is an isolated vertex.

The connected components of L(G_Ïƒ) induce subgraphs of G_Ïƒ, which are called lift components of G_Ïƒ. Thus, a lift component of G_Ïƒ is a maximal subgraph without isolated vertices whose lift matroid is connected, or it is an isolated vertex.

sentence: In an unsigned graph G, two vertices v and w are called parity connected if there exist both an odd-length and an even-length chain between them.  Equivalently, v and w are sign connected in G_-.  The graph G is called parity connected if every two vertices are parity connected in G; equivalently, G_- is sign connected.

sentence:
A signed graph G_Ïƒ is positively connected if every pair of distinct vertices is joined by a chain of positive sign.  The positively connected components of G_Ïƒ are the maximal positively connected subgraphs of G_Ïƒ.

Vertices u,v in G_Ïƒ are negatively connected if they are joined by a negative chain.  The relation of being negatively connected is not transitive, in general.  Therefore, we define a negatively connected component of G_Ïƒ to be a maximal subgraph in which every pair of vertices, u and v, is negatively connected, or has a third vertex w such that u and v are negatively connected to w.

A t-bar visibility representation of a graph assigns to each vertex
at most t horizontal bars in the plane so that vertices are adjacent if and
only if some bar assigned to one sees some bar assigned to the other via
an unobstructed vertical channel of positive width.
The bar visibility number of a graph G, denoted by b(G), is the
least integer t such that G has a t-bar visibility representation.

sentence:
Suppose that X is a digital image in ^n.  For each k â‰¥ 2, we have  a k-fold subdivision of X , which is an auxiliary (to X) digital image in ^n denoted by S(X, k), and also a canonical map or projection


    Ï_k  S(X, k) â†’ X


that is continuous in the digital sense. This goes as follows.   For a real number x, denote by âŒŠ x âŒ‹ the greatest integer less-than-or-equal-to x.  First, make
the [1/k]-lattice in ^n, namely, those points with coordinates each of which is z/k for some integer z, and then set


    S'(X, k) = { (x_1, â€¦, x_n) âˆˆ([1/k])^n  | ( âŒŠ x_1 âŒ‹, â€¦, âŒŠ x_n âŒ‹) âˆˆ X }.


Then set


    S(X,k) = { (kx_1, â€¦, kx_n) âˆˆ^n  | (x_1, â€¦, x_n) âˆˆ S'(X, k) }.


The map Ï_k is given by Ï_k( (y_1, â€¦, y_n) ) = ( âŒŠ y_1/k âŒ‹, â€¦, âŒŠ y_n/k âŒ‹), and one checks that this map is continuous.
For x âˆˆ X an individual point, we write S(x, k) âŠ† S(X, k) for the points y âˆˆ S(X, k) that satisfy Ï_k(y) = x.  If x = (x_1, â€¦, x_n) is a point in an n-dimensional digital image, then we may describe this set in general as


    S(x, k) = { (kx_1 + r_1, â€¦, kx_n + r_n) | 0 â‰¤ r_i â‰¤ k-1 }.


That is, for each x âˆˆ X, S(x, k) is an n-dimensional cubical lattice in ^n with each side of the cubical lattice containing k points.  Notice that  the result of subdivision therefore depends on the ambient space of the digital image.

for which f = ev_0âˆ˜H and g = ev_Nâˆ˜H.  Then H is a right homotopy from f to g.
